title-group.article-title: Clinical Transcriptome Sequencing Confirms Activation of a Cryptic Splice Site in Suspected SYNGAP1-Related Disorder

article-meta.aff: aDepartment of Neurology and Neurological Sciences, Stanford, CA
bDivision of Medical Genetics, Department of Pediatrics, Stanford Medicine, Stanford, CA
dDivision of Clinical Genetics, Virginia Commonwealth University Health System, Richmond, VA, USA

author-notes.corresp: *Elise Brimble, Department of Neurology and Neurological Sciences, Stanford Medicine, 291 Campus Drive, Li Ka Shing Building, Stanford, CA 94305 (USA), E-Mail ebrimble@stanfordchildrens.org

permissions.copyright-statement: Copyright © 2018 by S. Karger AG, Basel

abstract.p: SYNGAP1 encodes a brain-specific Ras GTPase activating protein (GAP) that regulates synaptic strength in glutamatergic neurons. Pathogenic variants in this gene are associated with a neurodevelopmental disorder characterized by intellectual and developmental disabilities, generalized epilepsy, hypotonia, and autism spectrum disorders. We describe a young male with suspected SYNGAP1-related disorder given clinical overlap and identification of an intronic variant of uncertain significance; clinical transcriptome analysis demonstrated activation of a cryptic acceptor splice site resulting in frameshift and introduction of a stop codon. This report highlights the utility of functional studies newly available to clinical practice in confirming a suspected genetic diagnosis, which can directly impact medical management and preclude the need for additional diagnostic testing.
